item.title: Greece Keeps Its Creditors Guessing
item.description: The suggestion by various Greek officials that Athens might not pay its debt obligations could be a negotiating tactic in debt talks.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: High-Speed Rail Aids Disaster Deployments by Chinese Military
item.description: The presence of uniformed personnel on a Shanghai train platform this week highlighted how high-speed rail had facilitated not just family reunions and business deals, but troop movements and disaster relief.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: Troops at the Shanghai Hongqiao Railway Station on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Scenes from the Tiananmen Memorial Events in Hong Kong
item.description: Twenty-six years after the military suppression of the protests at Tiananmen Square in Beijing, thousands gathered in Hong Kong to mourn those killed.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Tens of thousands gathered at the candlelight vigil at Victoria Park, Hong Kong, on Thursday to mark the 26th anniversary of the military crackdown on protests in Tiananmen Square, Beijing.

item.title: Relatives of Yangtze Ship Passengers Seek Answers Amid Search for Survivors
item.description: In all, 442 people are presumed dead, but families are still hoping to find out what happened the evening of the accident, and more grimly, when their loved ones’ bodies might be recovered.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: Chinese crews continued to search on Thursday for bodies from the capsized cruise ship in the Yangtze River.

item.title: South Korea Reports 3rd Death From MERS Virus
item.description: An 82-year-old man was the country’s latest victim of an illness that has forced over 1,160 schools and kindergartens to shut down temporarily.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Tourists wearing protective masks in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, as fears over Middle East respiratory syndrome, or MERS, continued to spread.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A New Role for Japan’s Military
item.description: A former ambassador of Japan to the United Nations argues that the country needs a military force that is able to defend both Japan and international peace.
item.dc:creator: SHINICHI KITAOKA

item.title: Gas Station Explosion in Ghana’s Capital Kills Around 100
item.description: The blast occurred overnight while the station was packed with people seeking shelter from knee-high water caused by rain that has flooded much of the city.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Thursday carrying a body from what remains of a gas station that exploded overnight in Accra, Ghana.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Young People Feel Less Invested in Fight for Democracy on Mainland
item.description: Divisions over how to commemorate the Tiananmen crackdown show how Hong Kong residents are increasingly seeing the push for a freer China as someone else’s fight.
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG and MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Tens of thousands gathered at the candlelight vigil at Victoria Park, Hong Kong, on Thursday to mark the 26th anniversary of the military crackdown on protests in Tiananmen Square, Beijing.

item.title: Ex-FIFA Official Jack Warner Threatens to Spill ‘Avalanche’ of Secrets
item.description: Mr. Warner said that he feared for his life and that he had evidence linking soccer’s governing body to an election in Trinidad and Tobago.
item.category: Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football (CONCACAF)
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Jack Warner, a former FIFA executive, at a meeting of his Independent Liberal Party in Trinidad and Tobago on Wednesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rival Pro-Democracy Rallies Planned for June 4 in Hong Kong
item.description: The various demonstrations are a reflection of growing divisions over Hong Kong’s identity, its relationship with the Chinese mainland and where democracy advocates should concentrate their efforts.
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.dc:creator: CRYSTAL TSE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: The candlelight vigil in Victoria Park in 2012 marking the 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen protests. A poll has found waning support for the vigil’s organizer.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: For NGOs in China, a Sense of Party Creep
item.description: Is Xi Jinping’s government pushing out the gains made by civil society since 1995, as some Chinese critics are whispering?
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Paramilitary officers marching on Tiananmen Square on March 5, 2015 before the opening session of the National People's Congress at the Great Hall of the People. Moves are afoot to tighten the management of both domestic and overseas NGOs in China.

item.title: Moldova, Hunting for Missing Millions, Finds Only Ash
item.description: The disappearance of the cash from three lenders, which are now insolvent, has exposed deep-rooted corruption and the power of business oligarchs.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: A branch of Banca de Economii in Chisinau, Moldova. Hundreds of millions of dollars have disappeared from that bank and two other Moldovan lenders.

item.title: Interpol Issues Alerts for 6 After Sepp Blatter Says He’ll Quit
item.description: The so-called red notices, issued at the request of the United States, were for two former senior FIFA officials and four corporate executives.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Interpol's so-called red notice alert for two former senior FIFA officials and four corporate executives.

item.title: Jacques Parizeau, Who Led Second Quebec Separatist Movement, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Parizeau wanted Quebec to secede from Canada to help it realize its potential, but after a second failed vote in 1995, he damaged his reputation with a speech explaining why the separatists lost.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Jacques Parizeau, then the Parti Québécois leader, acknowledging the crowd at an event in Montreal in October 1992.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has confirmed the deaths of two American service members.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Ex-Editor Cleared of Perjury
item.description: A former tabloid editor, Andy Coulson, was cleared of perjury as a judge said Wednesday that any lies he might have told under oath were not relevant to the trial in question.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Gaza: Militants Fire Rockets Into Israel
item.description: Palestinian militants launched two rockets from Gaza toward southern Israel late Wednesday, the Israeli military said.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: Burundi: Elections Delayed Amid Crisis
item.description: Frequent protests have left more than 30 people dead so far, activists say, and the turmoil made a timetable for parliamentary voting on Friday untenable.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Latvia: Defense Chief Elected President
item.description: After five rounds of voting, lawmakers on Wednesday chose Defense Minister Raimonds Vejonis as Latvia’s next president
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Argentina: Rallies to Protect Women
item.description: Thousands of people rallied in cities across Argentina on Wednesday to demand more robust action to prevent violence against women after a spate of murders.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
